metadata.title: Improved mechanical and antimicrobial properties of zein/chitosan films by adding highly dispersed nano-TiO2

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Industrial Crops & Products
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/indcrop
Improved mechanical and antimicrobial properties of zein/chitosan films by adding highly dispersed nano-TiO2 Liangfan Qu, Guiyun Chen, Shuang Dong, Yaoxing Huo, Zhonglin Yin, Shuhong Li, Ye Chen⁎
State Key Laboratory of Food Nutrition and Safety, Key Laboratory of Food Nutrition and Safety, Ministry of Education, College of Food Engineering and Biotechnology, Tianjin University of Science & Technology, Tianjin, 300457, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Zein Chitosan Nano-TiO2 Mechanical properties Antimicrobial activity
A B S T R A C T
Highly dispersible TiO2 nanoparticles were prepared through the hydrolysis of titanium alcohol, and a series of TiO2-modified zein/chitosan (CS) films were prepared through a process involving blending, solution casting and evaporation. The mechanical properties and the antibacterial capacity of the zein/CS/TiO2 films were characterized to explore the effects of different TiO2 nanoparticle contents. Results showed that the addition of nanoscale TiO2 remarkably improved the mechanical properties and thermal stability of the zein/CS/TiO2 film. The tensile strength of the zein/CS/TiO2 films significantly increased (p<0.05) with the increasing TiO2 loadings in films, reaching a maximum of 28.33±1.53 MPa at 0.15 wt % TiO2 nanoparticles. The antibacterial effect of the composite films on Gram-positive bacteria (S. aureus) was more significant than that of Gram-negative bacteria (E. coli and S. enteritidis), and the antibacterial effect of UV light was better than that of dark conditions. In particular, the inhibition zones of zein/CS/TiO2 (0.15%) film against E. coli, S. enteritidis and S. aureus under UV light condition increased by 21.78%, 21.45%, and 26.44%, respectively, compared with the control. This study suggested that adding highly dispersible TiO2 nanoparticles is an effective method for improving the mechanical and antimicrobial properties of zein/CS films for various applications, such as medical and food packaging.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Zein, a prolamin protein from corn, is soluble in 60%–95% ethanol. It behaves specifically as a hydrophobic protein because of a high composition of hydrophobic amino acids and acidic amino acid (Paliwal and Palakurthi, 2014). Compared with the most agriculturally-based protein, zein with glossy, tough, greaseproof, good film-forming characteristics and relatively good barrier properties are extensively studied for films and coatings (Yun et al., 2015). Sulfur amino acids (such as leucine and alanine) in zein can lead to strong intermolecular disulfide bonds as well as hydrophobic interactions between protein molecules, establishing the molecular basis for film-forming (Chen et al., 2018). The brittleness and stiffness of zein films, which cannot withstand industrial processing limits its application in the modern industry (Turasan et al., 2018).
Chitosan (CS), a copolymer of N-acetyl glucosamine and glucosamine linked by a b-1-4 linkage, is derived from chitin by partial deacetylation. Substantial CS exists in the exoskeleton of fungal cell walls and crustacean insects (Moran et al., 2018). Given its biocompatibility, biodegradability, excellent film-forming ability and inherent antibacterial and antifungal properties, CS has become one of the most widely used active packaging materials (Priyadarshi et al., 2018; Hu et al., 2016; Tan et al.,
2015). The antimicrobial activities of CS have been reported in many studies (Mujeeb Rahman et al., 2018; Kaya et al., 2018). Under acidic conditions, the positively charged -NH3+ groups of CS interact with the negatively charged bacterial cell membranes and produce bactericidal effects by affecting the permeability and destroying the integrity of the cell membrane (Chang et al., 2011).
Zein and CS were used as raw materials to produce composite materials. Escamillagarcía et al. (2013) used zein and CS to prepared an edible biopolymer film for reducing contamination. The composite films presented better water vapor barrier and mechanical properties than single ingredient films. A series of CS-modified zein composite films were fabricated from zein and CS by Yu et al. (Yu et al., 2017). With the content of CS from 0% to 50%, the thermal stability, water absorption, hydrophilicity. and tensile strength (TS) of the composite films also increased. Cheng et al. (2015) used zein and CS as a base material, adding phenolic compounds (ferulic acid, gallic acid) and carboxylic acid (adipic acid, succinic acid) to prepare an edible composite film. The ternary complex films exerted better water vapor barrier and TS properties, and elongation at break were 0.726 ± 0.078–2.589 ± 0.127MPa and 3.185 ± 2.083–22.710 ± 3.202%, respectively. While the inhibition percentages for films against
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.indcrop.2018.12.093 Received 12 March 2018; Received in revised form 19 November 2018; Accepted 29 December 2018
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: 13752758201@126.com (Y. Chen).
Industrial Crops & Products 130 (2019) 450–458
0926-6690/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
E. coli and S. aureus were around 10%–15% and 25%–30%, the content of phenolic compounds considerably increased the antimicrobial activity of the films.
The above researches indicated that zein/CS materials had insufficient mechanical and antibacterial properties, and it could not meet the demands of industrialization. Therefore, developing an appropriate modification method on zein/CS films with preferable functional properties can be expected. The addition of TiO2 nanoparticles has been widely reported as an effective material modification method (Mohsen et al., 2014; Zhang et al., 2016). In recent years, TiO2 nanomaterials have been gaining attention due to their unique properties, such as high chemical stability, high photocatalytic performance, high antimicrobial activity and biocompatibility (Lee and Park, 2013). A variety of methods have been successfully applied for the synthesis of TiO2 nanostructured materials with relevant properties: hydrothermal method (Gopal and Basha, 2018), liquid phase deposition (Lei et al., 2017), microemulsion method (Sanchez-Dominguez et al., 2015), chemical vapor deposition (Wang et al., 2014), plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (Nagasawa et al., 2018; Kusdianto et al., 2018), magnetron sputtering (Nuñez et al., 2017) and other routes such as laser ablation (Chaturvedi et al., 2017) and spray pyrolysis (Dostanić et al., 2013). The change of particle size has a great influence on the performance of the materials, thus, one of the important directions for the preparation of nanoTiO2 is to improve the particle dispersion. Directly adding the commercially available TiO2 powder in composite materials could result in self-agglomeration, precipitation and large particle size. This phenomenon will lead to the lack of mechanical properties, water resistance and antibacterial properties of materials. Compared with other preparation techniques, the sol-gel method controls the hydrolysis of titanium alkoxide to prepare TiO2 nanoparticles, which is simple in operation, mild in reaction conditions, low in cost and high in efficiency. The nanoparticle prepared through this method has high dispersity and good compatibility, therefore, it is a feasible method for improving the performance of TiO2 nanoparticles.
In this study, highly dispersible TiO2 nanoparticles were employed to improve the mechanical and antibacterial properties of zein/CS/TiO2 films. In addition, the mechanical properties, surface hydrophobic, water barrier, apparent and internal structures and thermal property of the films were also investigated. The antimicrobial activity of zein/CS/ TiO2 composite film under UV light irradiation and dark conditions were tested against three common microorganisms, E. coli, S. enteritidis and S. aureus, using the disc diffusion method.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Zein, regular grade was purchased from Gaoyourixing Industries Inc. (Jiangsu, China) with a protein content of 94.7%. CS, pharmaceutical grade was purchased from Golden-Shell Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd., (Zhejiang, China) with the deacetylation degree of 91% and molecular weight (Mw) of 100 kDa determined by ubbelohde viscometer. Titanium tetraisopropoxide (TTIP; 97%), purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China). Alcohol and Glacial acetic acid were purchased from Tianyi Industries Inc. (Tianjin, China). All the other chemicals were reagent grade and used as received without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Preparation of TiO2 nanoparticles precursor solution sample
sections.text:
TiO2 samples were prepared by the modified sol-gel method. The required reagents were ethanol, TTIP, hydrochloric acid and ultra-pure water. In the specific case, the reaction equation as follows:
Ti(OCH(CH3)2)4+2H2O→TiO2+4(CH3)2CHOH (1)
Firstly, solution A was prepared by mixing TTIP with two-thirds of amount of the ethanol. Secondly, solution B was prepared by mixing the
ultrapure water with hydrochloric acid, and the rest one-third of the ethanol. Then solution B was added to solution A, dropwise, under vigorous stirring at 500 r/min.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Preparation of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text:
Initially, the 0.12 g CS (6wt %) was dissolved in 1 v/v % Glacial acetic acid solution, stirred at 500 r/min for 2 h at room temperature with a magnetic stirrer. 16ml ethanol was added slowly into 4ml CS-glacial acetic acid solution and mixing for 10min at room temperature (25 °C). 2 g zein (10%, w/v) and 0.3 g glycerol (15wt %) were dissolved in the above solution by stirring for 10min at room temperature with a magnetic stirrer. TTIP precursor solution were then added to the zein-CS dispersions with a different TiO2 nanoparticles content in composite films, i.e. 0.05wt %, 0.10wt %, 0.15wt %, 0.20wt %, 0.25wt %, respectively.
After heating at 60 °C for 10min for full solutions, the films were formed by the casting-solvent evaporation technique by pouring 20ml of the Film-forming solution into a smooth, rimmed plastic plate and drying at 50 °C for 3 h and later maintaining at 25 °C in a desiccator which containing a saturated sodium bromide solution for least 7 days to provide a constant equilibrium relative humidity environment (53%±1%).

sections.heading: 2.3. Particle diameter measurement
sections.text: Particle diameter of TiO2 nanoparticles precursor solution sample and particle distribution were measured by a laser nanoparticle size analyzer (BT-90, Baite Co. Ltd., Dandong, China) at 25 °C (Dong et al., 2016). The scattered intensities were examined by applying the standard photon counting method.

sections.heading: 2.4. Mechanical properties measurements of zein/CS/TiO2 film
sections.text:
The mechanical properties, including the ultimate tensile strength (TS; MPa) and elongation at break (EAB; %) at rupture of zein/CS/TiO2 composite films, were evaluated using a texture analyzer (Shenzhen Reger Instrument Co., Ltd., Shenzhen, China) according to the well-established method (Chen et al., 2014) with slight modification. The films were cut into strips (100mm×10mm) and the cross-head speed was set at 10mm/s. The thickness was determined on each sample at 3 locations in the test section and the average values were used to calculate the TS and EAB. The elongation at break and ultimate TS of the films were determined in triplicate and estimated from the following equations:
= × TS MPa Ft T W ( ) (2)
= ×EAB L L(%) / 1000 (3)
where Ft is the maximum load recorded at film rupture (N), T is the thickness of the film (mm), W is the width of the film, ΔL is the elongation length of the film (mm), and L0 is the length of the film strip before testing.

sections.heading: 2.5. Scanning electron microscope (SEM)
sections.text: The surface microtopography of zein/CS/TiO2 films was characterized by using a scanning electron microscope (SU1510, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan). Before observation, a small amount of sample was pasted to stage with double-faced adhesive tape. The surface was coated with a thin layer of gold under vacuum for 5min. Then, they were put under the scanning electron microscope with an acceleration voltage of 5.0 kV and the surface morphology of the film's images was captured afterwards.

sections.heading: 2.6. Contact angle measurements
sections.text:
Surface contact angle is a prevalent parameter to evaluate wettability and surface energy. The contact angle measurements for zein/ CS/TiO2 films were determined by the sessile drop method with a JY-82
Video contact angle meter (Chengde DingSheng Tester Equipment Co., Ltd, Chengde, China). A drop of ultrapure water (5 μL) was placed on the surface of each composite film (20mm×20mm) using a microsyringe and observed through a microscope. For each film, five readings were tested at different positions of the surface of the composite film, and the average values were reported (Li et al., 2016a, b).

sections.heading: 2.7. Water absorption measurements
sections.text:
Water absorption was determined according to the method described by Yu et al. (2017). zein/CS/TiO2 films were cut into 2 cm× 2 cm pieces, weighting them (W1), and then immersing in ultrapure water at room temperature for 24 h. During the testing process, the films were taken out, and the excess of the medium on the surface was wiped off with filter paper. The films were weighed (W2) again. The water absorption ratio of zein/CS/TiO2 composite films (Wt) was calculated from the following equation:
= ×W W W W (%) 100t 2 1 1 (4)
where W1 is the initial weight of the composite membrane sample, and W2 is the weight of the composite membrane after the absorption of ultrapure water.

sections.heading: 2.8. Water vapor permeability (WVP) measurements
sections.text:
Water vapor permeability (WVP) of zein/CS/TiO2 composite films were determined according to the method reported in the literature (Hanani et al., 2014). Approximate 5 g dried anhydrous calcium sulfate was placed in each cup for the absorption of air water. The composite films were cut into circles of 2.5 cm in diameter and fixed on the top of the testing cup. Pre-weighed and sealed cups were placed in a humidistat containing a saturated sodium chloride solution at a relative humidity of 53 ± 1% and a temperature of 25 °C. Weighing the cups after 24 h. This procedure was repeated thrice to measure average WVP (g∙m/m2∙h∙Pa) values, which were calculated using the following equations:
= × × × WVP g m m h Pa W L t A P ( / )2 (5)
where ΔW is the weight change of the measuring cup (g), L is the thickness of the film (m), t is the measuring time (h), A is the surface area of the film sample (m2), and ΔP is the actual difference in partial pressure between the outside and inside of the film specimens (Pa).

sections.heading: 2.9. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR)
sections.text: Infrared spectra of zein/CS/TiO2 composite films were carried out by using a Thermo Nicolet iS 50 FTIR spectrometer (VECTOR22, Brook instruments Inc., Germany) from 4000–400 cm−1 to investigate the functional groups and structure conformation. Each measurement was an average of 16 scans at 4 cm−1 resolution, and attenuated total reflectance (ATR) mode was used to evaluate the series of composite film samples.

sections.heading: 2.10. Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA)
sections.text:
The changes in material mass loss with temperature were conducted as described by literature with minor modifications (Li et al., 2013). TGA analyses were carried out in a TG-DTA instrument (Q500, TA
Instruments Inc., USA) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen flow rate of 20mLmin−1. Approximately 2–5mg of sample was weighed as a standard and heated from 25 °C to 800 °C. The data of zein/CS/TiO2 films were collected every second.

sections.heading: 2.11. Antimicrobial activity test
sections.text:
The antimicrobial activities of the zein/CS/TiO2 composite films were determined using agar disc diffusion method. The microorganism, E. coli, S. enteritidis and S. aureus, were chosen for this study, as they were the most commonly found bacteria.
Bacteria were vaccinated in the solid culture medium, 40% relative humidity, 37 °C temperature in the incubator, activation for 24 h. The bacteria entered a stable logarithmic phase. The appropriate amount of activated bacteria was placed in the sterile saline, and the swirl oscillators were evenly distributed, and the suitable concentration of bacteria suspension was made. The solid culture medium by high pressure steam sterilization completely cooled to about 45 °C in a petri dish and then waited for it to solidify.
0.1ml of microbial cell suspension (105–106 CFU/ml) was spread on the surface of the solid medium with the applicator. The composite film samples, 6 mm outer diameter, was lightly attached to the center of the medium surface with tweezers. The antibacterial effect was evaluated by measuring the diameter of the antibacterial ring in dark and UV light (UV irradiation for 30min), respectively. They were cultivated 24 h under the condition of 40% relative humidity and 37 °C of temperature in the incubator. For each test, antimicrobial activity evaluations were performed in triplicate and the average value with standard deviation for all data was given.

sections.heading: 2.12. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Results were reported as the mean and standard deviation were analyzed using SPSS version 18.0 (SPSS, Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). Zein/ CS/TiO2 samples were statistically analyzed using Turkey’s multiple comparison test at p < 0.05 to detect significant difference between mean values. All figures were presented by Origin 8.0 software (Northampton, MA, USA).

sections.heading: 3.1. Particle size of nanometer TiO2
sections.text: The particle diameter distribution of nano-TiO2 prepared via the solgel method was shown in Table 1. Results indicated that the particle diameter of TiO2 nanoparticles prepared via the sol-gel method were between 5.12–6.29 nm. The TTIP was the intermediate of titanium, which dissolved in anhydrous ethanol, adding a certain amount of hydrochloric acid and water, and the highly dispersible TiO2 nanoparticles can be obtained via hydrolysis of titanium alcohol. HCl was used as a negative catalyst to inhibit the hydrolysis of TTIP by preventing the ionization of water molecules. In addition, the particle surface of the positive charge was attributed to the protonation of H+, and the diffusion layer was formed by an equal amount of opposite charges surrounding the charged particles in the solvent. The diffusion layer of the adjacent particles generated the repulsive force due to the overlap to overcome van der Waals force, which was caused by the close distance of adjacent particles. This action also helped suppress the further hydrolysis of TTIP.

sections.heading: 3.2. Mechanical properties of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text:
In the previous experiments, the best preparation technology of zein/ CS/TiO2 was selected as the index of TS. Based on this test, zein film loaded with 6wt % CS was selected as a control for the forthcoming
sample series (addition of TiO2 nanoparticles), in which the TS and EBA for control films were 22.33 ± 0.58MPa, 2.83 ± 2.89%, respectively. Different percentages of TiO2 nanoparticles were added to zein/CS film, and the corresponding mechanical properties were quantized in Fig. 1 (A and B). The TS of the zein/CS/TiO2 films significantly increased (p < 0.05) with increasing TiO2 loadings in the films, reaching a maximum of 28.33 ± 1.53MPa at 0.15wt % TiO2 nanoparticles and the TS reduced with further increases in nanoparticle content to 0.20wt%. The EBA of the film prepared with 0.15wt % and 0.20% TiO2 nanoparticles was slightly decreased; the highest EBA corresponded to the film, which was prepared with 0.05wt % TiO2 nanoparticles. Fill the main matrix with several nanoparticles is not necessary to obtain high mechanical properties; the excessive number of nanoparticles can reduce the mechanical properties of the composite film. The above phenomenon can be explained in two aspects. On the one hand, TiO2 nanoparticles played the role of the physical junction in composite film and improved its mechanical properties; on the other hand, the regularity of the network structure and the properties of the film can be weakened due to the aggregation of nanoparticles. Thus that during configuration of the zeinCS network, appropriate proportions of TiO2 nanoparticles can increase the interaction among various molecules, thereby reducing the EBA of film and improving its TS. Due to high interfacial area and energy, a high content of TiO2 nanoparticles properly formed stacked through the zein–CS matrix, so it could decrease the reinforcing effect, which is similar to nanohydroxyapatite powder/gelatin films (Wu et al., 2016). This result is consistent with El-Wakil, et al. (2015) who found that addition of 0.6% and 0.8% TiO2 nanoparticles to WG/CNC (7.5%) films significantly increased the TS, whereas a further increase in TiO2 nanoparticles (1%) resulted in a slight decrease in TS.

sections.heading: 3.3. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text:
SEM images of the surface and cross sections of zein/CS/TiO2 film morphology can be observed from Fig. 2. The addition of highly dispersible TiO2 was successfully applied to the preparation of zein/CS/ TiO2 films, with a better homogeneity of morphology. The surface of the composite film with TiO2 nanoparticles and control were smooth and occasionally had a porous and round squama-like structure. This phenomenon may be due to the fact that the dehydration rate of hydrophilic CS is slower than the hydrophobic zein (Hao et al., 2017). The homogeneous dispersion of nanoscale TiO2 in polymeric matrices is one
of the most important elements for making high performance composite materials. The TiO2 nanoparticles could be uniformly distributed on the zein/CS/TiO2 film on the surface and cross section. The addition of nano-TiO2 did not destroy the structure of zein-CS, which had good compatibility with the natural polymer matrix. The pictures revealed that the particle size of TiO2 in the composite films was approximately 1–100 nm, which was the basis for good antibacterial properties.

sections.heading: 3.4. Contact angle of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text: The water contact angle, which is the angle between the surface and the tangent line at the point of water droplet contacting with the surface, is a useful indicator for characterizing the average surface hydrophobicity of the modified material system (Romerobastida et al., 2016). Effects of TiO2 nanoparticle content on the water contact angle of zein/CS/TiO2 films are shown in Fig. 3. Zein exhibited low surface hydrophilicity and low surface wettability with a high contact angle value due to the high percentage of hydrophobic amino acids (Gu et al., 2013). From the results, the control film displayed a relatively hydrophobic surface, in which the water contact angle was 78.13°± 0.34°, whereas the value dropped dramatically after TiO2 nanoparticle treatment. When the content of TiO2 nanoparticles increased from 0% to 0.25%, the initial water contact angle of the zein/CS/TiO2 films decreased from 78.13°± 0.34° to 71.64°± 0.99° because of the relatively high hydrophilic properties of TiO2, which was similar to the previous report from Nayak et al. (2015). Subsequently, the contact angle of the composite film changed gradually and steadily. A slight difference was observed in the contact angle at 5 s, which were 65.72°± 0.55°, 65.36°± 0.49°, 65.08°± 0.2°, 64.46°± 0.41°, 64.29°± 0.73°, and 63.77°± 0.73°. The presence of oxygen vacancy on the surface of TiO2 nanoparticles resulted in highly hydrophilic micropores around the Ti3+ defect, whereas water could be adsorbed in oxygen vacancies, leading to the increase in contact angle with the increase in TiO2 content. Zhang et al. (2017) used TiO2 nanopowder to modify CS films, and the contact angle of CS/TiO2 film decreased from 98.0 ± 1.2° to 44.4 ± 1.5° compared with the pure CS film, illustrating enhanced surface hydrophilicity when incorporating TiO2 nanoparticles. In summary, this result indicated a slight decrease in the hydrophobicity of film with the addition of TiO2 nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.5. Water absorption of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text:
The water absorption of zein/CS/TiO2 films soaked in ultrapure water for 24 h are shown in Fig. 4. Compared with the zein/CS film, the water absorption of the zein/CS/TiO2 films was strongly reduced after the addition of TiO2 nanoparticles. During the 24 h of soaking, the water absorption of zein/CS/TiO2 films (n) (n=0%, 0.05%, 0.10%, 0.15%, 0.20%, and 0.25%) were 666.19%, 659.38%, 446.80%,
312.94%, 320.94%, and 652.19%, respectively. Generally, the water absorption of hydrophilic materials soaked in ultrapure water should be higher than that of the hydrophobic ones. In this work, the water absorption of composite films was mainly affected by the hydrophilicity of CS, given the higher water absorption rate.
Substantial studies (Li et al., 2018) have shown that the inclusion of nanoparticles can remarkably reduce the water absorption rate of a natural polymer film, probably because of the minimal nanoparticle addition and lack of reunion, which were “inlaid” in the film uniformly. Moreover, the composite film showed better performance because of the frictional force between nanoparticles and the zein-CS polymer matrix. The TiO2 nanoparticle reunion increased the particle size increase when excessive amounts of nanometer TiO2 were added, the number of nanoscale TiO2 between interfaces decreased, and the compatibility between the large aggregates and the film was deteriorated. Small holes on the surface and interior of zein/CS/TiO2 films emerged, which increased the water absorption rate of the films. Results showed that the water absorption of the composite film reached the minimum when 0.15% TiO2 nanoparticles were added.

sections.heading: 3.6. Water vapor permeability (WVP) of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text:
Fig. 5 shows the dependence of WVP upon the addition of different concentrations of TiO2 nanoparticles on zein/CS/TiO2 films. The WVP value of zein/CS/TiO2 films with nano-TiO2 was lower than that of the control. The higher WVP of the control film may be ascribed to the phase separation of different natural macromolecular compounds during zein/CS film preparation. The WVP values of the control film and films prepared at different percentages of TiO2 nanoparticle content were statistically significantly different. The WVP of the zein/CS/TiO2 (n) (n=0%, 0.05%, 0.10%, 0.15%, 0.20% and 0.25%) films were 13.6 ± 0.19, 13.09 ± 0.52, 12.96 ± 0.15, 12.19 ± 0.28, 12.81 ± 0.29, and 13.34 ± 0.38× 10−8 g∙m/m2∙h∙Pa, respectively, which suggested that an increase in TiO2 nanoparticle content decreased the WVP value of the film by 11% when added with 0.15% TiO2 nanoparticles. Previous reports indicated that the resistibility of the film against vapor permeation was closely connected to the micropaths in the network microstructure of matrix (Li et al., 2011).
The hydrophilicity of the CS molecules leads to the comparatively poor moisture barrier properties of the zein/CS/TiO2 films. Modified TiO2 nanoparticles facilitated the compatibility of zein and CS molecules, which improved the water tolerance and moisture resistance of films. It is postulated that the TiO2 nanoparticles combined with the zein and CS matrix tightly filled the gaps within the network structure, creating a tortuous way for water vapor molecules to permeate the film. Therefore, TiO2 nanoparticle addition improved water vapor barrier properties. Results were in consistent with a study on the incorporation of TiO2 nanocomposites in a gluten/nanocellulose film to decrease theFig. 3. Water contact angle of zein/CS/TiO2 films with different TiO2 contents.
WVP values of the film (El-Wakil et al., 2015). Similar results were obtained in a study of Zolfi et al. (2014), in which kefiran/whey protein reduced water solubility WVP, moisture content and moisture absorption by increasing the TiO2 nanoparticle content.

sections.heading: 3.7. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text:
The zein/CS/TiO2 films were characterized by FTIR spectroscopy technique. The representative spectra of the zein/CS/TiO2 films are exhibited in Fig. 6. The FTIR spectrum of zein/CS film that exhibited a broad intense band at 3301 cm−1 were attributed to the vibrational stretching of −OH and -NH groups. Close to this wavelength, -N-H and -O-H groups vibrational stretching was universally verified (Hong et al., 2018). Moreover, peaks at wave numbers around 2958 cm−1 and 2874 cm−1 in zein/ CS film samples mainly stemmed from the asymmetrical and symmetrical stretching vibrations of methyl, respectively. Peaks at wave numbers around 2934 cm−1 represented the asymmetrical stretching vibration of the C–H in CH2 and CH3 groups (Tongnuanchan et al., 2014). The peak of amide band at 1653 cm−1 was assigned to C]O and C–N, indicating the occurrence of peptide bond vibrational stretching. The intense bands at 1544 cm−1 was ascribed to the characteristic absorption of C–N group stretching vibrations and NeH group bending vibrations of amide II (He et al., 2016). The other peak of the amide band at 1452 cm−1 was attributed to the C–H deviational vibration predominates.
Furthermore, all films displayed the same vibrational peaks at the same wavenumbers. These results indicated that no obvious changes in the shift or density of the peaks belonging to zein/CS occurred regardless of different contents of nano-TiO2. Moreover, results were consistent with the work of Li et al. (2016a, b), in which TiO2-modified composite membrane did not have a characteristic peak of TiO2, which may be due to the low amount added.

sections.heading: 3.8. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analysis of zein/CS/TiO2 film samples are exhibited in Fig. 7, and the corresponding thermal degradation values are shownin Table 2. Results were consistent with the previous studies (Piai et al., 2010); the weight loss could be observed in two stages. The initial degradation temperature of approximately 61.55 °C to 67.09 °C on mass between 6.564% and 6.997% were induced by the water vaporization and other components, such as residual volatile ethanol from the film. This irregularity can be explained by the compatibility of zein and CS and the difference of moisture content in the composite film. Afterward, the TGA curves for the different TiO2 concentrations of zein/CS/TiO2 films presented considerable mass loss; this event was more intense for the composite film without TiO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 7).
The next maximum decomposition rates of different composite films were determined at temperatures of 263.52 °C, 268.14 °C, 270.19 °C, 288.57 °C, 282.97 °C, and 268.44 °C, respectively, which could be attributed to the thermo-oxidative degradation of organics of the film, the removal of strongly bound water or surface hydroxyl groups, and elimination of volatile products. As the content of TiO2 nanoparticles increased, the initial temperature of degradation initially increased and then decreased, whereas the total degradation rate of the composite films gradually decreased, illustrating that the thermal stability of zein/ CS/TiO2 films was superior to that of zein/CS films without appropriate modification by TiO2 nanoparticles. The reason may be well related to the fact that TiO2 nanoparticles could promote the interaction among various molecules in a certain concentration range, as the formation of a three-dimensional network structure increased density and rigidity; High levels of TiO2 nanoparticles not only affected the molecular chain activity but also reduced the relative unit of motion, which hindered the cross-linking between the different molecules and affected the regularity of the network structure. In summary, the optimal thermal stability of the composite film was determined adding 0.15% TiO2 nanoparticles were added.

sections.heading: 3.9. Antimicrobial activity of zein/CS/TiO2 films
sections.text:
The inhibitory effects of zein/CS/TiO2 films on the growth of E. coli, S. enteritidis and S. aureus are exhibited in Table 3. The inhibitory diameter of the composite membrane against the three bacteria under UV irradiation was larger than that under dark conditions, although no
significant difference was found in antibacterial activity among the composite films with different TiO2 contents under dark condition for 24 h Fig. 8 and 9 . The antibacterial properties against E. coli, S. enteritidis and S. aureus of zein/CS/TiO2 (0.15%) films under UV light condition increased by 21.78%, 21.45%, and 26.44%, respectively. Particularly, results from the antibacterial activity of S. aureus
suggested that in the absence of TiO2 nanoparticles, zein/CS film resulted in 31.07 ± 1.21mm and 26.62 ± 0.11mm diameter of inhabiting circles under UV light and dark conditions after 24 h of incubation, respectively. This result can be attributed to the inactivation of UV light on S. aureus. Furthermore, in the presence of TiO2, TiO2 at 0.05%, 0.10%, 0.15%, 0.20% and 0.25% possessed 34.40 ± 0.72, 35.85 ± 0.78, 37.35 ± 0.68, 35.55 ± 0.49, and 33.06 ± 0.63mm diameter of inhabiting circles under UV light condition, respectively. Moreover, the inhibition of the other two bacteria has a similar trend. Therefore, the antimicrobial activity of the zein/CS/TiO2 film may be required for the ratio of TiO2 nanoparticles.
The antimicrobial capacity of CS on Gram-positive bacteria was confirmed to be more powerful than Gram-negative bacteria (Chang et al., 2015; Azuma et al., 2014). One of the reasons that CS has antibacterial properties is that the positively charged amino groups interact with the microbial cell membrane, which could react with the anionic groups of the microbial cell surface, resulting in the leakage of protein and other intracellular constituents of the microorganism (Mousavi et al., 2018). CS can form a polymeric layer on the surface of the gram-positive bacteria, which can inhibit the entry of nutrients into the cell, thereby leading to cell death (Zheng and Zhu, 2003). In addition, the antimicrobial performance of CS is attributed to the inhibition of mRNA and protein synthesis via the penetration of CS into the nuclei of microorganism. The formation of an external barrier and chelating metals decreased the availability of essential nutrients to necessary for microbial growth. TiO2 nanoparticles can produce hydroxyl radicals (−OH) and other reactive oxygen species under irradiation with UV light. The free radicals with strong activity can directly destroy the unsaturated bonds on the surface of the bacteria, allow sugar depolymerization, lipid decomposition and protein denaturation on the surface of bacteria, and then enter the bacterial cell to destroy its internal structure further and inactivate it inactivation. In addition, it may release toxic metal ions that results in bacterial inactivation and cell membrane damage of the bacteria is ascribed to the direct contact of nanoparticles (El-Shahawy et al., 2018).
Li et al. (2016a, b)prepared CS/TiO2 nanocomposites and measured antimicrobial properties of the material. The antibacterial activity against Xanthomonas oryzae pv. Oryzae was significantly higher than that of the two individual components under light and dark conditions. The antibacterial properties were significantly improved by the combination of CS and TiO2. Furthermore, in agreement with this result, a new type of bactericidal and antifungal fabric was prepared by fixing CS/TiO2 composite on cotton fiber, which showed high bactericidal rate against A. niger, E. coli and S. aureus (Qian et al., 2011).
Results showed that compared with the single component of CS, CS and TiO2 nanoparticles had considerable synergistic antibacterial effect, which had stronger antibacterial activity against E. coli, S. enteritidis and S. aureus under dark and UV light irradiation conditions. In summary, this study suggests that zein/CS/TiO2 composite films as a potential antimicrobial material, inhibit microbial growth.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In this study, zein/CS/TiO2 films were prepared and the physicochemical and structure features of the films were investigated. Nanoscale TiO2-modified by films showed better mechanical properties, thermal stability and hydrophobic property than the unmodified one. In particular, the antibacterial properties of zein/CS/TiO2 (0.15%) films against E. coli, S. enteritidis and S. aureus under UV light condition increased by 21.78%, 21.45%, and 26.44%, respectively. This research established an important precedent to consider the use of TiO2 nanoparticles precursor solution for the properties of composite film properties.

Compared with the most agriculturally-based protein, zein with glossy, tough, greaseproof, good film-forming characteristics and relatively good barrier properties are extensively studied for films and coatings (Yun et al., 2015).

Sulfur amino acids (such as leucine and alanine) in zein can lead to strong intermolecular disulfide bonds as well as hydrophobic interactions between protein molecules, establishing the molecular basis for film-forming (Chen et al., 2018).
The brittleness and stiffness of zein films, which cannot withstand industrial processing limits its application in the modern industry (Turasan et al., 2018).

In recent years, TiO2 nanomaterials have been gaining attention due to their unique properties, such as high chemical stability, high photocatalytic performance, high antimicrobial activity and biocompatibility (Lee and Park, 2013).

Due to high interfacial area and energy, a high content of TiO2 nanoparticles properly formed stacked through the zein–CS matrix, so it could decrease the reinforcing effect, which is similar to nanohydroxyapatite powder/gelatin films (Wu et al., 2016).
This phenomenon may be due to the fact that the dehydration rate of hydrophilic CS is slower than the hydrophobic zein (Hao et al., 2017).

The water contact angle, which is the angle between the surface and the tangent line at the point of water droplet contacting with the surface, is a useful indicator for characterizing the average surface hydrophobicity of the modified material system (Romerobastida et al., 2016).
Zein exhibited low surface hydrophilicity and low surface wettability with a high contact angle value due to the high percentage of hydrophobic amino acids (Gu et al., 2013).

Substantial studies (Li et al., 2018) have shown that the inclusion of nanoparticles can remarkably reduce the water absorption rate of a natural polymer film, probably because of the minimal nanoparticle addition and lack of reunion, which were “inlaid” in the film uniformly.
Previous reports indicated that the resistibility of the film against vapor permeation was closely connected to the micropaths in the network microstructure of matrix (Li et al., 2011).

The intense bands at 1544 cm was ascribed to the characteristic absorption of C–N group stretching vibrations and NeH group bending vibrations of amide II (He et al., 2016).

One of the reasons that CS has antibacterial properties is that the positively charged amino groups interact with the microbial cell membrane, which could react with the anionic groups of the microbial cell surface, resulting in the leakage of protein and other intracellular constituents of the microorganism (Mousavi et al., 2018).

metadata.abstractText: Highly dispersible TiO2 nanoparticles were prepared through the hydrolysis of titanium alcohol, and a series of TiO2-modified zein/chitosan (CS) films were prepared through a process involving blending, solution casting and evaporation. The mechanical properties and the antibacterial capacity of the zein/CS/TiO2 films were characterized to explore the effects of different TiO2 nanoparticle contents. Results showed that the addition of nanoscale TiO2 remarkably improved the mechanical properties and thermal stability of the zein/CS/TiO2 film. The tensile strength of the zein/CS/TiO2 films significantly increased (p<0.05) with the increasing TiO2 loadings in films, reaching a maximum of 28.33±1.53 MPa at 0.15 wt % TiO2 nanoparticles. The antibacterial effect of the composite films on Gram-positive bacteria (S. aureus) was more significant than that of Gram-negative bacteria (E. coli and S. enteritidis), and the antibacterial effect of UV light was better than that of dark conditions. In particular, the inhibition zones of zein/CS/TiO2 (0.15%) film against E. coli, S. enteritidis and S. aureus under UV light condition increased by 21.78%, 21.45%, and 26.44%, respectively, compared with the control. This study suggested that adding highly dispersible TiO2 nanoparticles is an effective method for improving the mechanical and antimicrobial properties of zein/CS films for various applications, such as medical and food packaging.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
